properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow continues today. Conditions are favourable for heavy snow to continue over the Coquihalla highway today. 5 to 10 cm of snow has been reported at some locations along the highway this morning. Total accumulations up to 25 cm can be expected by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T09:07:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T17:08:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1789009742.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A weather system moving in from southern Alberta will spread snow into west-central Saskatchewan around midnight. The snow will then push eastward across the northern grainbelt on Tuesday. Southern and east-central Saskatchewan however will experience mostly rain with this system, although some areas will change over to flurries as colder air comes in later in the day. There is also a risk of freezing rain beginning late this evening in the Kindersley region, spreading through Saskatoon and Melfort overnight and Tuesday morning. North Battleford and Prince Albert also have a risk of freezing rain, although it is more likely south of those communities. The situation will be monitored closely, and freezing rain warnings may be required as precipitation from the system starts to move in. Some accumulating snow is also expected, with 2 to 4 cm likely at Saskatoon but 5 to 10 cm through North Battleford and Prince Albert. Meadow Lake will receive the most with up to 15 cm in their forecast. Currently a snowfall warning is in effect for Meadow Lake, but this may shift into other regions depending on the track of the system. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T13:51:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T21:52:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3731377431.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-01T00:37:43-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Locations: northeastern and eastern Newfoundland. Time span: until early this morning. Remarks: Freezing drizzle, at times mixed with flurries or drizzle, is expected to continue until temperatures rise above zero this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-31T14:59:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T07:40:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3370974025.2020
Area: Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h and falling snow will produce blizzard conditions in Arviat beginning this evening. Blizzard conditions will gradually diminish Wednesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-01T00:21:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T08:22:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4210910244.2020
Area: Arviat

properties.Summary:

Conditions are favourable for heavy snow to continue over sections of the Coquihalla highway and Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass. Additional snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm can be expected by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A weather system moving in from southern Alberta will spread snow into west-central Saskatchewan around midnight. Snow will then push eastward across the northern grainbelt on Tuesday. Southern and east-central Saskatchewan however will experience mostly rain with this system, although some areas will change over to flurries as colder air comes in behind the system. There is also a risk of freezing rain overnight and Tuesday morning through the Kindersley, Saskatoon, Melfort, North Battleford and Prince Albert areas. Snowfall totals in the Meadow Lake region will be in the 10 to 15 cm range, with about 5 to 10 cm forecast from North Battleford through Prince Albert, then lesser amounts further south. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T13:41:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-30T21:42:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1708388348.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. A cold air mass over the region combined with strong winds are causing windchill values near minus 55. Conditions will improve Tuesday morning as the winds ease. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T14:59:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T05:20:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2137887358.2020
Area: Kugaaruk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow beginning Tuesday afternoon changing to rain Wednesday. Snowfall total: 2 to 5 cm. Rainfall total: 15 to 35 mm except possibly exceeding 40 mm in the northeast. Location: eastern New Brunswick. Remarks: A warm front moving westward off the Gulf of St. Lawrence will bring a few cm of snow to New Brunswick beginning Tuesday afternoon. Precipitation will change to rain on Wednesday as temperatures rise above zero. An extended period of rain is then expected to last until Thursday night, when temperatures should fall below zero again. At this time, precipitation should change to flurries and taper off by Friday morning. Temperatures will remain above freezing through the overnight hours on Wednesday. The rain and mild temperatures could lead to significant melting of the snow pack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T16:36:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T00:37:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3414390070.2020
Area: Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system moving into Saskatchewan tonight will spread heavy snow into northern Saskatchewan beginning early Tuesday morning. Snow will continue to fall throughout the day on Tuesday before tapering off Tuesday night. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T14:04:03-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain on the way for mid week. Rainfall totals: 15 to 35 mm. Location: northern and eastern Nova Scotia including Cape Breton. Time span: Wednesday and Thursday Remarks: Rain will begin on Wednesday morning as a warm front passes westward through the Gulf of St. Lawrence and into New Brunswick. This rain could persist through the day on Thursday. Heaviest rainfall amounts are expected along the eastern shore of Nova Scotia and eastern Cape Breton Island. The rain, combined with mild temperatures may cause significant melting of any remaining snowpack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T16:36:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T00:37:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2392614422.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system is forecast to develop in southern Alberta this evening and track eastward into Saskatchewan overnight. This system will bring heavy snow to central Alberta starting this evening and will end Tuesday morning. For the Fort McMurray region, the heaviest snow will begin early Tuesday morning and start to ease during the day on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm continues. A low pressure system continues to produce heavy snow. Snow will taper off Tuesday morning in central Alberta and Wednesday morning for northern Alberta. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow beginning Tuesday morning changing to rain Wednesday morning. Snowfall total: 2 to 5 cm. Rainfall total: 15 to 30 mm except possibly exceeding 40 mm over Prince County. Location: Prince Edward Island. Remarks: A warm front moving westward through the Gulf of St. Lawrence will bring a few cm of snow to the Island beginning early Tuesday morning. As temperatures rise behind the front, precipitation will change to rain on Wednesday morning and persist into Thursday. Temperatures will remain above freezing even during the overnight hours on Wednesday. The rain and mild temperatures may lead to significant melting of the snow pack and runoff. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T16:36:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-31T00:37:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0810588207.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system is forecast to develop in southern Alberta this evening and track eastward into Saskatchewan overnight. This system will bring heavy snow to central Alberta starting this evening and will end Tuesday morning. For the Fort McMurray region, the heaviest snow will begin early Tuesday morning and start to ease during the day on Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T13:59:00-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm continues. A prolonged period of snowfall continues to impact communities in northern Manitoba, with another 5 to 10 cm expected to accumulate tonight. While snow from this first system will gradually taper off later tonight, a second disturbance is expected to cross northwestern sections of the province Tuesday night into Wednesday, potentially bringing another 10 to 15 cm of snow to those areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-31T13:00:48-00:00
